On Fri, 16 Mar 2001, David M. Goudreau wrote:

> Does anyone have any opinions, suggestions or approaches as to how to best
> implement JUnit AFTER development has started?  We have a significant code
> base already and we're trying to move to JUnit.  What issues did you have
> when trying this yourself?  Was your testing hierarchy exactly the same as
> your application package structure?  Did you start only using JUnit with new
> development or with bugs as well?  Or did you take a month off and have
> everyone write JUnit tests?  Any help would be greatly appreciated.

I pretend to do XP for one.  What I did when I started using JUnit was
to pick an interesting existing class, and write tests for just that class,
as a learning exercise.

All new code is written test-first (unless it's a spike.)  

Before I change a pre-existing class I write tests for it.  If it's
a big class I may write tests covering the behavior I'm changing.
IE If I'm changing a method on a Java bean which deals with one field,
and that field doesn't influence some other fields, I may not take the
time to write tests right now for those other fields.

Writing tests for existing classes is on my @todo list but they're nowhere
near the top.  I have a very deep @todo list. :/

If I've acquired new 3rd party code with sources, and it doesn't come
with its own tests (most don't) then I'll often write tests for the
classes/methods I'm using, often as a learning exercise.
